questions.text: What is the most appropriate next step in the management of a female patient who has abdominal pain, multiple gallstones with no thickening of the gallbladder wall as seen on ultrasound, a common bile duct diameter of 12mm, serum bilirubin level of 0.8, alkaline phosphatase level of 380, and a 5-fold increase in GGT?
questions.solution:
• The patient has multiple gallstones, and the CBD diameter is increased at 12mm, which suggests the possibility of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct).
  • The elevated alkaline phosphatase and significantly raised GGT levels also indicate some degree of biliary obstruction.
  • MRCP can accurately assess the CBD and help identify the presence, location, and size of any stones within the duct.
  • It can also evaluate the pancreatic duct for any associated pathology. By obtaining this information, MRCP can guide further management decisions and determine the most appropriate intervention, whether it's endoscopic or surgical.

 

ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) (Option B) ERCP can be therapeutic and used for stone removal, it is typically reserved for cases where there is a clear indication for intervention, such as symptomatic choledocholithiasis or evidence of biliary obstruction with significant symptoms or abnormal liver function tests.

 

Endoscopic ultrasound (Option C) EUS can be useful for evaluating certain conditions, such as pancreatic tumours or staging of gastrointestinal malignancies, it is not the primary modality for assessing gallstones or the biliary system.

 

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option D)in this case, the focus is primarily on the evaluation of the biliary system. Therefore, performing a cholecystectomy without further assessment and identification of possible choledocholithiasis would be premature.

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

Explanation:

  • Acute pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas, often linked to biliary causes like gallstones or choledocholithiasis; however, when choledocholithiasis is absent, and no bile duct obstruction is present, ERCP is not typically recommended.
  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is an invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to examine and treat disorders of the bile ducts, pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder.
  • In the given case, non-invasive imaging like abdominal ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI is sufficient to assess the pancreas and biliary tree, and ERCP is reserved for patients with evidence of bile duct obstruction.

 

Recurrent pancreatitis (Option A) can be caused by bile duct stones, pancreatic duct abnormalities, or strictures. ERCP helps by identifying obstructions, structural changes, and stones in the bile duct or pancreatic duct. It also allows therapeutic interventions such as stone removal or stenting of the bile duct. Therefore, ERCP is often used in recurrent pancreatitis if there is suspicion of biliary causes.

Unexplained jaundice (Option B) can arise from a variety of causes, but one of the most common is obstruction of the bile duct, often by stones, tumours, or strictures. ERCP is an excellent diagnostic tool for identifying the cause of jaundice.

Periampullary mass (Option C) is a growth near the Ampulla of Vater, and ERCP is particularly useful in the diagnosis of these as it provides detailed imaging of the ampulla of Vater and helps identify the location, extent, and nature of the mass, aiding in further management decisions.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She had a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, abdomen auscultation revealed high-pitched bowel sounds. Investigations showed air within the biliary tree. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gallstone ileus

Explanation:

The patient, with a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years ago, presents with abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation, and investigations revealing air within the biliary tree, indicating Gallstone ileus.

  • A rare complication of cholelithiasis (0.4%) caused by the impaction of one or more gallstones within the gastrointestinal tract, is more common in the elderly and women.

 

Pathophysiology:

  • Acute cholecystitis→ erosion of inflamed tissues → Formation of a cholecystointestinal fistula→ Gallstone ileus
  • Small gallstones typically pass through the intestines, but stones 2–5 cm in size can become impacted, usually in the terminal ileum or at the ileocecal valve.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction.
  • Signs of obstruction include dehydration, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice. (Option A)

 

Diagnosis:

  • Plain Abdominal Radiograph:
    • Partial or complete intestinal obstruction
    • Pneumobilia or contrast material in the biliary tree
    • Calcified gallstone with position changes on serial films (tumbling sign)
  • CT Scan:
    • Superior sensitivity (up to 93%)
    • Shows abnormal gallbladder with air, air-fluid level, or fluid accumulation with an irregular wall (Option A)

Management:

  • Management of intestinal obstruction
  • Enterolithotomy: The most common surgical procedure
    • A longitudinal incision on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of impaction
    • Gallstone is brought to a non-edematous bowel segment by gentle manipulation and extraction.
  • Cholecystoenteric fistula resection only if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus.

 

Adhesive intestinal obstruction (Option B) occurs when scar tissue from previous abdominal surgery causes bowel loops to stick together, leading to obstruction. It typically presents with symptoms of bowel obstruction (pain, vomiting, distention) but would not show air in the biliary tree.

Ischemic enterocolitis (Option C) results from reduced blood flow to the intestines, often due to arterial blockage or low blood pressure. It causes diffuse abdominal pain, tenderness, and sometimes bloody diarrhoea, but does not cause the air in the biliary tree.

Diverticulitis (Option D) is inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon. It usually presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits, and does not cause air in the biliary tree.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serum lipase

Explanation:

  • The patient's severe abdominal pain and CT scan showing fluid-filled lesions near the body of the pancreas suggest an inflammatory process, diagnosed as Pancreatitis, with elevated serum lipase levels.

Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3):

  1. Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
  2. Serum amylase and/or lipase (more specific) level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal.
  3. Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis.

X-ray Features
  • Sentinel loop sign:
    • Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localised ileus.
    • Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

 

Sentinel loop sign
  • Colon cut-off sign:
    • Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.
    • Significance: Suggests localised pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

 

Investigations of Choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications.
    • Most reliable for staging and detecting complications.
    • It may underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours.

Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  • Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis: Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis.
  • Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality.

 

Serum GGT (Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase) (Option A) is elevated in liver disease, especially in cases of alcohol abuse, but it's not specific to pancreatitis.

CEA (Option B), carcinoembryonic antigen, is a tumour marker not typically elevated in pancreatitis.

Serum bilirubin (Option D) may be elevated in biliary obstruction or liver disease; it is not a primary marker for pancreatitis.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy for gallstones 2.5 years ago. She now presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Investigation reveals a stone in the common bile duct. What is the stone most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Recurrent

Explanation:

  • The given scenario, where a patient has a history of cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) for gallstones 2.5 years ago and is now presenting with obstructive jaundice and a gallstone in the common bile duct (CBD), indicates a case of recurrent type of Common Bile Duct Stones (Choledocholithiasis).

Types

  • Retained common bile duct stones
    • Detected within 2 years of cholecystectomy
  • Recurrent common bile duct stones
    • Detected after 2 years of cholecystectomy (Option D)

Clinical features
  • Charcot’s triad : Pain + Fever + Jaundice
  • Reynauld’s pentad: Mental status changes + Hypotension + Charcot’s triad
  • Biliary colic: A sudden, severe, colicky pain in the right upper quadrant that radiates to the back and shoulder, precipitated by a fatty or heavy meal, and can last for a few hours.
  • Darkening of the urine and lightening of the stools.
  • Steatorrhea, or fatty stools
  • Pruritus (itching), loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis
  • Pancreatitis
  • Liver Damage
  • Biliary Stricture
  • Gallstone Ileus

 

MRCP of CBD stone

 

      ERCP of a distal CBD stone

 

Primary (Option A) forms inside the common bile duct (CBD), with brownstones being the most common type. These stones are often associated with underlying conditions such as primary sclerosing cholangitis or Caroli disease.

Secondary (Option B) are those that form in the gallbladder and later migrate into the common bile duct (CBD). The most common type is cholesterol stones, which can subsequently move into the CBD.

Tertiary (Option C) are formed within the bile ducts as a result of bacterial or parasitic infection.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in the management of a female patient who experienced abdominal pain and increased heart rate three days after cholecystectomy? Her white blood cell count is 11000 cells / mm^3, and an ultrasound examination revealed a 5x5 cm accumulation of fluid in the sub-hepatic space on the right side.
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) USG-guided pigtail catheter drainage

Explanation:

  • The next step in managing a woman who presented with abdominal pain and tachycardia, with a fluid collection in the right sub-hepatic space seen on ultrasound, is USG-guided pigtail catheter drainage as this is a case of bile duct injury following cholecystectomy.
  • Ultrasound-guided pigtail catheter drainage offers several advantages, including improved accuracy in locating the fluid collection and minimizing the risk of complications.

 

Antibiotics and send home (Option A) The presence of a fluid collection and symptoms suggestive of postoperative complications necessitates intervention rather than sending the patient home with antibiotics alone.

Laparoscopy and re-exploration (Option C) are not the first-line management options for a fluid collection in the subhepatic space. Less invasive measures like drainage should be attempted first.

ERCP and T-tube placement (Option D) are indicated in biliary tract-related issues, which may not be the primary cause of the fluid collection in this scenario.

questions.text: What is the most helpful test to identify the underlying cause in a 56-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice, who presents with a distended gall bladder, dilated common bile duct, and enlarged intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

  • Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is:

    • A non-invasive imaging modality.

    • Excellent for visualising the biliary tree and pancreatic ducts.

    • Particularly useful in obstructive jaundice to evaluate:

      • Site of obstruction

      • Cause (e.g., stones, strictures, tumours)

      • Extent of biliary dilatation

  • It does not require contrast injection into the ducts and has no risk of pancreatitis or infection, unlike ERCP.

INVESTIGATIONS - CHOLEDOCHAL CYST

Endoscopic Ultrasound

(Option B ruled out)
  • The first imaging test that is performed.
  • Confirms the presence of the cyst.
  • Reveals anatomical details, including bile duct and pancreatic duct relationship.

Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Non-invasive imaging technique. Provides detailed images of the gallbladder and biliary system.
  • Highly sensitive (>90%) and specific (>99%) for identifying common bile duct stones.
  • Visualizes biliary anatomy and the extent of dilatation.

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):

(Option D ruled out)
  • Invasive procedure with endoscope and contrast material.
  • Diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities (tissue sampling, decompression, treatment of choledocholithiasis).
  • Effective but has a complication rate of up to 10%.

Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC)
  • Invasive procedure with a needle directly into the liver.
  • Useful for intrahepatic biliary disease or when ERCP is not feasible. (Option C ruled out)
  • Helps delineate surgical anatomy and enables drainage catheter and stent placement.

CT SCAN

Mainly to see the intrahepatic biliary system

Other Tests
  • Hepatobiliary nuclide Scanning
  • Liver Function Tests

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is/are correct?

1. TACE(Transarterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions

2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

3. The incidence of HCC is increasing

4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC
questions.solution:
Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) - Explanation of Statements

Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. TACE (Transarterial Chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.

True

TACE is used in intermediate-stage (BCLC B) HCC with multiple nodules and preserved liver function (Child-Pugh A/B).

2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm.

False

Lenvatinib is a systemic therapy for advanced HCC (BCLC C). Small (<3 cm) tumors are treated with resection, RFA, or liver transplant.

3. The incidence of HCC is increasing.

True

The incidence of HCC is rising globally due to increased metabolic syndrome, NAFLD/NASH, obesity, and hepatitis B/C.

4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

True

NAFLD/NASH are leading non-viral causes of HCC. They can cause HCC even in non-cirrhotic livers due to chronic inflammation.


 

1, 2, 3 (Option A) It includes the incorrect statement that Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm. Lenvatinib is an approved systemic therapy for advanced HCC

2, 3, 4 (Option B) It includes the incorrect statement that Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm.

1 and 2 (Option D) It does not include the correct statement that NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

questions.text:
A 40 year old woman presented with jaundice, fever, and abdominal pain. She is suspected to have cholangitis. Which of the following apart from abdominal pain makes up Reynold pentad?

 

1. Fever

2. Jaundice

3. Hypotension

4. Altered sensorium

5. Hematemesis

6. Melena
questions.solution:
Reynold’s Pentad is seen in severe (suppurative) cholangitis, which includes:

1. Fever with chills

2. Jaundice

3. Hypotension (Shock)

4. Altered mental status (Confusion, delirium)

5. Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain

 

Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

2, 3, 4, 5 (Option B) Includes hematemesis, which is NOT a feature of Reynold’s Pentad.

1, 3, 4, 5 (Option C) Misses jaundice and includes hematemesis, which is NOT a feature of Reynold’s Pentad

1, 2, 4, 5) (Option D) Includes hematemesis, which is unrelated to cholangitis. I

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak is suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ERCP

Explanation:

  • In the context of a suspected bile leak after cholecystectomy, the best investigation is typically ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
  • It can help confirm the presence of a bile leak, localise the site, and allow for therapeutic intervention, such as stenting, which may resolve the leak.

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

Definition

It is an invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to examine and treat disorders of the bile ducts, pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder.

Indications
  • It allows for visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater.
  • Allows biopsies, stone extraction, and other Interventional procedures like sphincterotomy, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilation.

In Jaundice

Less suitable for jaundiced patients as it is invasive

Imaging Type

Provides dynamic information during contrast introduction

Image

MRCP (Option A) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can help visualise bile ducts, but it doesn't provide the same ability for therapeutic intervention as ERCP.

HIDA (Option C) (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) is useful for evaluating biliary patency and assessing bile flow. Though it can be used for detecting bile flow abnormalities, it cannot be used for therapeutic management, hence ERCP is generally considered the best for diagnosing and managing bile leaks.

CECT (Option D) can be used to detect collections or fluid accumulation and its evaluation but it lacks the therapeutic intervention that ERCP can offer. Additionally, CECT involves radiation exposure and may not be the optimal choice when a more specific investigation like ERCP is available.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 42-year-old woman who came with symptoms of fever, vomiting, and right hypochondriac pain, which radiates to the neck? She has experienced similar episodes in the past, and a positive Murphy's sign was observed during the examination.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute cholecystitis

Explanation:

  • Murphy's sign: when we place the fingers on the right hypochondrium and ask the patient to take deep inspiration. At the height of inspiration, there is a sudden catch. This catch is due to an inflamed gallbladder coming in contact with the abdominal wall. This produces pain.
  • In the case of acute cholecystitis, there is inflammation of the gallbladder, and Murphy's sign is positive.

 

Murphy’s sign is not positive in carcinoma of the gallbladder (Option B), peptic ulcer (Option C), or acute appendicitis (Option D), as it is specifically associated with acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back, which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appeared icteric, and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Pancreatic pseudocyst

Explanation:

  • Pancreatic pseudocyst is a complication seen after 2 weeks of an acute pancreatitis attack. It is commonly seen in alcoholism.
  • The cyst is usually located between the stomach and transverse colon, between the stomach and liver or Behind or below the transverse colon.
  • Clinically a tense cystic mass in the epigastrium, umbilical region or left hypochondrium can be seen.

 

Large choledochal cyst (Option B) Choledochal cyst is a congenital cyst and is not caused due to alcoholism. It is not seen as a tense mass in the epigastrium.

Gastric duplication cyst (Option C) It is a congenital cyst and is not caused by alcoholism. It is seen usually in relation to the distal region of the greater curvature. There is no clinically evident tense mass near the epigastrium.

Mesenteric cyst (Option D) This cyst is congenital

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Pancreaticojejunostomy:

Explanation:

  • The procedure shown in the above image is pancreaticojejunostomy. Puestow's operation is indicated for diffuse chronic pancreatitis and dilated pancreatic duct. questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with acute epigastric pain and fever. He has a history of cholelithiasis. On examination, abdominal guarding and rigidity are noted. Laboratory results show elevated serum amylase and lipase levels, along with leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis for his condition?

choices.text: Serum amylase remains elevated even after 30 days of resolution of acute pancreatitis
﻿﻿﻿> 75 per cent of patients present with hypercalcemia
Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase
Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis here is acute pancreatitis, given the acute epigastric pain, fever, history of cholelithiasis, abdominal guarding, rigidity, & elevated serum amylase and lipase levels along with leukocytosis.
  • Serum lipase is indeed more specific than amylase for diagnosing acute pancreatitis.
  • While both enzymes are elevated in pancreatitis, lipase tends to remain elevated longer and is more directly associated with pancreatic damage. (Option A ruled out)
  • Serum amylase levels can also be elevated in other acute abdominal conditions such as perforation, volvulus, and torsion.
  • If amylase remains elevated for more than a few weeks, it could indicate a chronic condition or other non-pancreatic diseases.

> 75 per cent of patients present with hypercalcemia (Option B):

  • Hypercalcemia is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis.
  • In fact, hypocalcemia is more commonly observed in acute pancreatitis, which happens due to the precipitation of calcium salts in the pancreatic tissue because of the saponification of fat.

Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity (Option D):

  • Lipase and amylase do not directly correlate with the severity of the disease, and none of the commonly used scoring systems for grading pancreatitis directly rely on the values of amylase or lipase to assess the severity of the condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back for the past 1 day and has had 3 episodes of vomiting. The pain radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position. The following signs are seen on examination and lab investigations reveal elevated lipase and amylase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • The image shows Cullen’s sign, which is superficial edema with bruising in the subcutaneous fatty tissue around the peri-umbilical region, as well as the Grey Turner sign, which is flank ecchymosis.
  • These signs are indicative of acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is characterised by pain in the abdomen that radiates to the back and is relieved in the sitting forward position.
  • Elevated lipase and amylase are seen in acute pancreatitis.

 

Acute Appendicitis (Option A) Pain typically starts as periumbilical and later localizes to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) (McBurney’s point). No back radiation or elevated lipase/amylase.

Acute Cholecystitis (Option B) presents with RUQ pain, Murphy’s sign (+), and fever. No back radiation or lipase elevation unless complicated by gallstone pancreatitis.

Acute Ischemic Colitis (Option D) presents sudden severe abdominal pain (out of proportion to clinical findings), often in elderly patients with vascular disease. No elevated lipase/amylase or back radiation.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows a ‘colon cut-off sign’. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

Acute Pancreatitis

Feature

Description

Definition

Acute inflammation of the pancreas due to premature enzyme activation, leads to autodigestion.

Common Causes (Mnemonic: "I GET SMASHED")

Idiopathic, Gallstones (most common), Ethanol, Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion sting, Hyperlipidemia/hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs (thiazides, azathioprine).

Clinical Features

Severe epigastric pain (radiates to back, worsens after food), nausea, vomiting, fever. Severe cases: Cullen’s Sign (periumbilical bruising), Grey Turner’s Sign (flank bruising), Colon Cutoff Sign (gas-filled, distended transverse colon with abrupt cut-off at splenic flexure due to inflammation).(Option B)

Diagnosis (Atlanta Criteria)

≥2 of 3 criteria: (1) Lipase >3x ULN (more specific than amylase), (2) Epigastric pain, (3) Imaging (CT/USG/MRI) evidence. CT scan (best for complications), Ultrasound (detects gallstones).

Severity Classification

Mild: No organ failure, Moderate: <48 hrs organ failure, Severe: >48 hrs organ failure.

Management

IV Fluids (Ringer’s lactate), NPO (Bowel Rest), Pain Control (IV opioids), and Enteral feeding are preferred over TPN. ERCP only if gallstone pancreatitis with cholangitis. No routine antibiotics unless infected necrosis.

Complications

Early (<1 week): SIRS, Shock, ARDS, Renal failure, DIC, Hypocalcemia. Late (>1 week): Necrosis (sterile/infected), Pseudocyst, Abscess, Chronic Pancreatitis, Biliary obstruction.

Acute hepatitis (Option A) Symptoms of acute hepatitis are fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, light-coloured stools, joint pain, and jaundice.

Acute colitis (Option C) In colitis, the mucosal lining of the colon becomes acutely or chronically inflamed. Symptoms of patients with colitis include watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, tenesmus, urgency, fever, subjective fatigue, or blood in the stool.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D) Intestinal obstructions present with dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels on abdominal x-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Steatorrhea

Explanation:

Complications of Cholecystectomy

Category

Complication

Description/Features

Early (Intraoperative & Immediate Postoperative)

Bile Duct Injury

Accidental damage to the common bile duct (CBD) leads to bile leakage or strictures (More common in laparoscopic cholecystectomy).

Hemorrhage

Bleeding from the cystic artery or liver bed; managed with hemostasis or blood transfusion if severe.

Bowel Injury

Unintended injury to the duodenum or colon, is rare but serious.

Anesthesia-related Complications

Aspiration, respiratory depression, hypotension, and arrhythmias.

Early Postoperative (0–7 Days)

Infection (Wound/Port-Site Abscess)

Fever, erythema, tenderness at the incision site. More common in diabetics or immunocompromised patients.

Bile Leak (Biloma)

Fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and localized fluid collection on imaging. Often from cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct injury.

Subhepatic Collection (Abscess)

Fever, RUQ pain, and tachycardia; requires percutaneous drainage.

Retained Gallstones

Residual gallstones in the bile duct can cause biliary colic or cholangitis postoperatively.

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) & Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Due to prolonged immobilization, leading to leg swelling or sudden dyspnea (Prevent with early ambulation, anticoagulation).

Late Postoperative (>7 Days – Months/Years)

Steatorrhea (Fatty Stools)

(Option C)

Most common long-term issue due to continuous bile secretion, leading to fat malabsorption.

Post-Cholecystectomy Syndrome (PCS)

Persistent dyspepsia, bloating, diarrhea, or RUQ pain due to bile reflux or remnant stones.

Biliary Strictures

Chronic narrowing of the CBD, leading to jaundice and cholangitis.

Chronic Diarrhea

Related to altered bile acid metabolism, may require bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine).

Increased Risk of Colorectal Cancer (Debatable)

Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but evidence is weak.

Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) (Option A) Not a common direct complication of cholecystectomy; it could occur due to severe infection or intraoperative hypotension, but it is rare.

Osteoporosis (Option B) No direct link; chronic fat malabsorption (as in severe bile acid diarrhoea) can lead to vitamin D deficiency, but this is uncommon in routine cholecystectomy cases.

Colorectal Cancer (Option D) Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but it is not a direct or common consequence of cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent pain in the right hypochondrium, nausea, and vomiting is diagnosed with biliary dyskinesia. Which of the following is least useful in the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) USG

Explanation:

  • Biliary dyskinesia is a functional disorder of the gallbladder, characterised by abnormal motility and diagnosis is typically made through tests that evaluate gallbladder function rather than its structure.
  • USG is good for detecting structural abnormalities, but it does not assess gallbladder function.
  • It presents with intermittent upper abdominal pain and nausea, particularly after eating, when your gallbladder attempts to contract (biliary colic) and the insufficient bile in the intestine leads to bloating, nausea, vomiting, and poor digestion, especially after consuming fatty foods.
  • HIDA scan is useful in diagnosis, as it evaluates gallbladder function using a radioactive tracer. (Option B ruled out)


ERCP (Option A) is not the first-line test for biliary dyskinesia, but it is used to assess biliary dysmotility by using a manometry. It is also useful for visualizing the biliary ducts and can help rule out anatomical causes of biliary pain; it also provides an opportunity for therapeutic interventions if needed.

Post-surgery follow-up (Option D) is not used to diagnose biliary dyskinesia but is important for monitoring recovery and addressing complications, as well as for managing and assessing the patient's condition after surgical intervention.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with fatigue. Imaging revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones and a large stone in the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Explanation:

  • The next step in the management of this patient is ERCP, which is used to relieve biliary obstruction caused by the stone in the common bile duct.
  • It is a procedure that combines endoscopy and fluoroscopy to visualise and treat conditions affecting the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts.
  • It allows for the removal of common bile duct stones, dilation of strictures, and placement of stents to relieve biliary obstruction.
  • It has both diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities.
  • Stones up to 12 mm can usually be removed by Endoscopic Retrograde.

Choledocholithiasis

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis: Bacterial infection due to obstructed bile flow, leading to fever, chills, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  • Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas due to obstruction at the ampulla of Vater.
  • Liver Damage: Prolonged obstruction can cause biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.
  • Biliary Stricture: Chronic inflammation can lead to the narrowing of the bile ducts.
  • Gallstone Ileus: Large gallstone eroding into the intestine, causing mechanical obstruction.

Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy (Option A): Cholecystectomy is the surgical removal of the gall bladder. When there is an active obstruction of the bile duct, the focus should first be on relieving the biliary obstruction before considering cholecystectomy. Once the obstruction is addressed, the patient can undergo cholecystectomy to prevent future complications.

Wait and watch (Option C) is not appropriate in this case because the patient has an impacted stone in the common bile duct with associated dilation of the biliary tree and is symptomatic. If left management is delayed, it could lead to complications.

CT scan (Option D) may provide additional information about the extent of the biliary tree dilatation and the presence of other abnormalities, but it does not address the immediate need for intervention to relieve the biliary obstruction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Explanation:

The patient's age, male predominance, along with MRCP findings of (beading) multiple irregular stricturing and dilatations of the bile duct, suggest Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

PSC is characterised by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of extrahepatic and large intrahepatic bile ducts, with dilation of preserved segments.

Demographics
  • It commonly occurs in individuals aged 30-50 years.
  • Has a male predominance of 2:1.

Pathogenesis
  • It suggests an immunologically mediated process supported by circulating autoantibodies and T lymphocytes in the periductal stroma, as well as associations with HLA-B8 and ulcerative colitis.
  • A mix of environmental & genetic factors may trigger bile duct injury.
  • Increased risk of PSC in first-degree relatives indicates a genetic component.
  • Activated T cells from ulcerative colitis mucosa may migrate to the liver, targeting bile duct antigens.
  • Changes in the intestinal microbiome or infections may alter cholangiocytes, causing inflammation.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are

Clinical features
  • Common symptoms include fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice.
  • Nearly 50% of patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, often identified through elevated serum alkaline phosphatase.
  • Ascending cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic cholecystitis may also occur.
  • Fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis over 10-15 years.

Characteristic findings
  • ERCP/MRCP shows the beaded appearance of bile ducts
  • Biopsy,
    • Early features:
      • Periductal "onion skin" fibrosis & inflammation
      • Portal edema & bile ductular proliferation
    • Later stages show progressive fibrosis leading to biliary cirrhosis and obliterative cholangitis, resulting in "vanishing bile duct syndrome"

Associated conditions

Ulcerative colitis, risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma

Complication

Lifetime risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is about 20%.

Caroli disease (Option B) is a rare congenital condition characterised by cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. On MRCP, it shows diffuse bile duct dilation with saccular and fusiform features, along with a peripheral funnel-shaped sign. Unlike PSC, Caroli disease typically involves only the intrahepatic ducts, without extrahepatic duct involvement.

Oriental cholangitis (Option C) is seen in Asian populations and is often related to hepatolithiasis and biliary tract infections. It doesn’t normally show the beaded appearance on MRCP, which is more characteristic of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary biliary carcinoma (Option D) is also known as Cholangiocarcinoma and presents with obstructive jaundice, but it doesn’t usually cause recurrent fever and chills as cholangitis does. On MRCP, it shows focal or diffuse bile duct strictures or mass lesions rather than the beaded appearance.

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. Upon examination, there was tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes, and abdominal ultrasound, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described, along with the ultrasound provided her,e suggests Hydatid disease.
  • The given ultrasound shows a characteristic waterlily sign, indicating a cyst with a detached membrane floating within the cyst cavity, which is a hallmark of stage CE 3.

Causative agent

Echinococcus granulosus

Commonly Affected Organs
  • Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases)
  • Lungs (second most common site)
  • Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum

Clinical Features

Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth.

Symptomatic Phase:

  • Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension.
  • Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax.

Investigations

Imaging Studies:

  • USG is the first-line imaging modality, particularly for liver involvement.
    • Features: Echinococcal cyst wall shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour)
  • CT Scan
  • MRI

Serological Tests:

  • ELISA
  • Immunoblotting

Other tests:

  • Casoni Intradermal Test
  • ARC5 Immunoelectrophoresis

 

Amoebic liver abscess (Option A) can cause pain and liver enlargement, they are more common in individuals who have a history of travel to endemic areas and typically present with an abscess in the liver, not a cyst.

Pyogenic liver abscess (Option C) are mostly caused by bacterial infections and are more likely to present with fever, chills, and more localized pain. They would not typically cause the marked eosinophilia seen in this case.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option D) can cause liver enlargement; it is a malignant tumour and generally doesn't present with the eosinophilia or characteristic ultrasound findings seen in parasitic infections.

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. A picture of the resected gall bladder is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gall bladder carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The given image shows a resected gall bladder with features suggestive of carcinoma, it is typically nodular and infiltrative, causing thickening of the gall bladder wall, which may extend to the entire gall bladder.
  • It is often difficult to differentiate from chronic cholecystitis.

Gall bladder carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Gallstones, (The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population)
  • Porcelain gallbladder,
  • PSC,
  • Abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction

Presentation
  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage)

Lab investigation
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging & Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

Mixed stone in gall bladder (Option B) refers to gallstones composed of a mixture of cholesterol, bilirubin, and calcium salts. They are normally identified through imaging methods such as ultrasound and may not appear visibly as a carcinoma.

Cholecystitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the gall bladder, often due to gallstones or infection. It can present with acute symptoms like pain, fever, and nausea. Imaging shows gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, & ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

Choledocholithiasis (Option D) refers to the presence of stones in the common bile duct, and its diagnosis typically requires imaging to show stones in the bile duct.

questions.text: What is the term for a stone obstructing the cystic duct, causing dilation of the common hepatic duct, resulting in CBD obstruction and jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mirizzi’s syndrome

Explanation:

  • The condition described in the question is known as Mirizzi’s syndrome.
  • Mirizzi's syndrome is seen in 1% of all cholecystectomies, where a gallstone impacts the gallbladder wall, leading to compression and pressure necrosis.
  • This often results in adherence to the common hepatic duct (CHD) or common bile duct (CBD) wall and can occasionally lead to a cholecystocholedochal fistula.
  • It leads to biliary obstruction, which can result in jaundice and dilation of the bile ducts (CHD and CBD).

Mirizzi’s syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • The gallstone usually impacts from the Hartmann's pouch, leading to compression of the CHD/CBD.
  • Can also occur from the fundus of the gallbladder into the CBD.

Clinical features
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Upper abdominal tenderness on the right side
  • Possible palpable soft, enlarged liver

Csendes Classification

Type I - Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Type II - The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd of the circumference of the CBD/CHD, forming a fistula

Type III - Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHD

Type IV - Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

Type V - Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

Investigations
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial imaging to assess gallbladder and ducts.
  • CT Scan: Provides detailed imaging of the biliary system.
  • ERCP/ MRCP: Essential for delineating duct anatomy and identifying the site of obstruction.
  • HIDA Scan: Useful for functional assessment of the biliary system.
  • Findings: Dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary system with a block at the common hepatic duct (CHD).

 

Acute cholecystitis (Option A) is inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct. While this condition can cause pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, it does not commonly cause dilation of the common hepatic duct or jaundice unless there is a secondary obstruction of the CBD or cystic duct.

Porcelain gallbladder (Option B) refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall, usually due to chronic cholecystitis. This condition is associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer but does not cause biliary obstruction or jaundice due to stone impaction in the cystic duct.

Cholesterolosis (Option C), also called strawberry gallbladder, involves lipid deposits in the gallbladder mucosa, leading to a characteristic appearance on imaging. It is often asymptomatic and does not typically cause biliary obstruction or jaundice.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman had her routine follow-up, and her USG of the liver is shown below. She is asymptomatic at present but has a history of mild right hypochondriac pain, which is relieved by taking analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gallstones

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Gallstones, based on the USG findings of a thickened gallbladder wall with biliary sludge, acoustic shadowing and the patient's history of mild right hypochondriac pain that responds to analgesics.
  • Gallstones can sometimes be asymptomatic or present with mild right upper quadrant pain, which is relieved by analgesics. This suggests biliary colic rather than an acute infection.
  • Biliary sludge, often seen on imaging, is a precursor to gallstones and can occur due to stagnation of bile in the gallbladder, often in the presence of gallstones.

Amoebic liver abscess (Option B) presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and liver enlargement. It is often seen in patients with a history of amoebic dysentery (entamoeba histolytica infection). The USG would show a hypoechoic mass in the liver, which is not consistent with the findings in this case.

Hydatid cyst (Option C) is caused by Echinococcus tapeworm infection and is usually found in the liver. The USG appearance of a hydatid cyst typically shows water-lily signs multilocular cysts, or honeycomb patterns, which is not seen here. Symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice.

Acute cholecystitis (Option D) presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and Murphy's sign (pain on palpation of the right upper quadrant). It generally presents more acutely and is associated with inflammation and infection, leading to more severe symptoms.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon carefully identifies the boundaries of the hepatocystic triangle to avoid injury to important structures. Which of the following is not a boundary of the hepatocystic triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cystic artery

Explanation:

  • Cystohepatic triangle, also known as the Calot's triangle, is an important anatomical area during gallbladder surgery.
  • Cystic artery is a structure that passes through the triangle but it's not a border.
  • The boundaries of Calot's triangle are defined by:
    • Cystic duct - Lateral boundary
    • Common hepatic duct - Medial boundary
    • The inferior surface of the liver - Superior boundary
  • Contents:
    • Cystic artery (supplies blood to the gallbladder)
    • Cystic lymph node (Lund’s node)
    • Autonomic fibers reaching the gallbladder

questions.text: A 46 year male had a tumor in his left lobe of liver, so left sided hemi hepatectomy was planned, which of the following lobes of liver will be resected in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:

Explanation: Liver lobes are defined surgically based on Couinaud's segmental anatomy (functional anatomy), which follows the portal vein and hepatic vein divisions rather than the classical anatomical right/left lobes.

In a left hemihepatectomy, the left functional lobe is removed.

  • This includes segments II, III, and IV:
    • Segment II & III: Left lateral section
    • Segment IV: Left medial section

Segments of the liver

Segment VIII:

  • The superior part of the right anterior sector.
  • Drainage: Drains into the right and middle hepatic veins.

Segment I (Caudate Lobe):

  • Posterior to segment IV, straddles the inferior vena cava.
  • Drainage: Multiple small veins drain directly into the inferior vena cava.
  • Bile Ducts: Related to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts.

Segment II:

  • Posterolateral to the left portal fissure.
  • Drainage: Drains into the left hepatic vein; rarely directly into the inferior vena cava.

 

Segment VII:

  • The superior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right hepatic vein.
  • Drainage: Primarily into the right hepatic vein; occasionally directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment III:

  • Between the umbilical and left portal fissures.
  • Drainage: Primarily into the left hepatic vein; alternative drainage via falciform ligament veins.

Segment VI:

  • Inferior part of the right posterior sector, posterior to the right portal fissure.
  • Drainage: Usually into the right hepatic vein; may drain directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment V:

  • Inferior segment of the right anterior sector.
  • Drainage: Typically into the right and middle hepatic veins; can drain directly into the inferior vena cava.

Segment IV:

  • Between the umbilical fissure and main portal fissure, anterior to segment I.
  • Drainage: Usually into the middle hepatic vein; can also drain into the left hepatic vein.

1, 2 & 3 (Option B): Segment I is the caudate lobe, which is functionally separate and not routinely removed in a left hemihepatectomy.

5, 6, 7 & 8 (Option C): These are part of the right functional lobe.

2, 3, 4 & 5 (Option D): Segment 5 belongs to the right lobe.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen after 4 days of cholecystectomy. On USG, it showed a significant collection in RUQ. What will you do further?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. USG-guided aspiration of content

Explanation:

  • The patient presents 4 days post-cholecystectomy with a localized collection in the right upper quadrant on ultrasound. The immediate priority here is diagnosis and therapeutic drainage — aspiration will relieve symptoms, confirm the nature of the fluid (bile, pus, blood), and guide further management. If the aspirated content is bile → further evaluation with MRCP or ERCP can be planned to localize and treat the leak. Aspiration is minimally invasive and avoids unnecessary re-exploration in a stable patient.

Post-Cholecystectomy Collections:

  • Causes: Bile leak (cystic duct stump leak, accessory duct injury), intra-abdominal abscess, hematoma, seroma.
  • Symptoms: Fever, abdominal pain, localized tenderness, distension, jaundice (if major duct injury).
  • Diagnosis:
    • USG: Detects and localizes fluid collection.
    • Aspiration: Confirms content type.
    • MRCP: Maps biliary anatomy if a bile leak is suspected.
    • ERCP: Diagnostic + therapeutic (stenting, sphincterotomy).
  • Surgical anatomy:
    • Calot’s triangle boundaries → Cystic duct (medial), common hepatic duct (lateral), inferior surface of liver (superior).
    • Contents: Cystic artery, cystic lymph node of Lund, connective tissue.

  • Management pathway:
    • USG-guided aspiration.
    • If bile leak → MRCP/ERCP.
    • Persistent leak or large duct injury → surgical repair.

Re-explore laparoscopically (Option A) – Too invasive without knowing the nature of the collection.

Higher antibiotics (Option B) – Won’t resolve a large collection; drainage is required.

MRCP (Option C) – Useful after confirming bile in the aspirate, but here aspiration is the first step.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type A

Explanation:

According to the Bismuth-Strasberg classification, the image shows a Type A injury, which involves a cystic duct stump leak or leakage from small ducts in the liver bed, and is the most common type, typically occurring without damage to the major bile ducts.

E2: Main bile duct injury, less than 2 cm from the confluence

E3: Hilar injury with intact confluence

E4: Injury involving the confluence; right and left hepatic ducts are separated

questions.text: A patient presents with a 2-year history of anorexia, epigastric pain, jaundice, and itching (pruritis). On examination, the gallbladder is palpable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Ca of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ca of the head of the pancreas

Explanation:

Prolonged anorexia, epigastric pain, jaundice, and pruritis with a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier’s sign) indicate chronic biliary obstruction, most commonly caused by carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

CA Pancreas

  • Symptoms:
    • Jaundice secondary to obstruction is the most common symptom
    • Characteristically painless, but may be associated with nausea and epigastric discomfort
    • Pruritus, dark urine and pale stools with steatorrhea
    • Weight loss
  • Signs:
    • Courvoisier’s sign - palpable, non-tender gallbladder (Option D)
    • Palpable liver and ascites
    • Diabetes mellitus depending on the location of tumor

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option A): Although gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice and a palpable gallbladder, it is less common and usually presents with more localized symptoms.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option B) rarely causes biliary obstruction or a palpable gallbladder.

Cholelithiasis (gallstones) (Option C) usually causes episodic pain and does not present with a palpable gallbladder or chronic jaundice.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy, and the histopathology reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscular layer. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extended Cholecystectomy

Explanation:

  • T1b lesions refer to gallbladder cancer that invades the muscular layer but not beyond the deeper layers. The next best step is extended cholecystectomy to ensure an R0 resection, which includes removal of the surrounding lymph nodes (e.g., hepatoduodenal, gastrohepatic) and possibly part of the hepatic parenchyma to achieve clear margins.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pain, jaundice, fever
 

Explanation:

Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Pain, jaundice, shock (Option B): This option is incorrect as shock is not part of Charcot's triad but is part of Reynolds's pentad.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic patient presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Blood investigations reveal increased serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of alcohol consumption, along with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and significantly elevated serum amylase and lipase levels, points strongly toward acute pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis:

  • Clinical features:
    • Pain (severe, constant, and often resistant to common analgesics).
    • In about 50% of patients, the pain radiates to the back, and some patients may find relief by sitting or leaning forward.
    • Nausea and vomiting are usually prominent, and retching may persist even with nasogastric aspiration.
  • Examination findings:
    • Patient's condition: well to severely ill with signs of shock and toxicity.
    • Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension are commonly observed.
    • Mild icterus may suggest biliary obstruction (in gallstone pancreatitis).
    • SIRS may be present
    • Bluish discolouration (Grey Turner’s sign or Cullen’s sign).
    • Abdominal distension due to ileus or ascites is common, and muscle guarding is often present.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum amylase level > 3x the normal value is strongly indicative.
    • Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than amylase.
    • CECT scan is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Mild cases may be managed with IV fluids, analgesics, and antiemetics.
    • Nil per os (NPO) is typically advised initially to avoid stimulating the pancreas.
    • Antibiotics are not generally indicated unless there is suspicion of infection
  • Management of severe cases:
    • Admit to intensive care or a high-dependency unit for close monitoring.
    • Aggressive fluid resuscitation is critical, guided by vital signs, urine output, and central venous pressure.
    • Oxygen supplementation and serial blood gas analysis.
    • If nutritional support is necessary, enteral feeding via nasogastric tube is preferred over parenteral nutrition.
  • Management of specific complications:
    • Antibiotics may be indicated if cholangitis or other infections are suspected. Prophylactic antibiotics should not exceed 14 days.
    • If gallstone pancreatitis is suspected and there is biliary obstruction, ERCP should be performed within 72 hours.
  • Complications:
    • Shock, arrhythmias, ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), renal failure, and DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation).
    • Metabolic derangements like hypocalcemia, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia may occur.
    • Peripancreatic fluid collection, pancreatic abscess, pseudocyst, and pancreatic necrosis.
    • Pleural effusion, pancreatic ascites, and pancreatic haemorrhage (pseudoaneurysm) are also common.

Incorrect Options:

Peptic ulcer disease (Option A) typically presents with epigastric pain, but it doesn't radiate to the back & does not cause elevated amylase and lipase levels.

Acute cholecystitis (Option C) presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, often with fever and nausea, but it is not typically associated with marked increases in amylase and lipase. This condition would usually show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin.

Pyogenic liver abscess (Option D) can present with fever and abdominal pain, but it does not typically cause significant increases in amylase and lipase. This condition would be more likely to show abnormal liver function tests and may be associated with other findings like fever or jaundice.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice. Biliary atresia is suspected when jaundice is persistent and exceeds?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 weeks

Explanation:

  • Biliary atresia is a serious condition that causes bile ducts to become obstructed or absent, leading to cholestasis and liver damage. In newborns, jaundice that persists beyond 2 weeks is a key clinical sign of biliary atresia, as physiological jaundice typically resolves within the first 1-2 weeks of life.

Extra-Hepatic Biliary Atresia:

  • Also known as Non-Cystic Obliterative Cholangiopathy.
  • Characterised by complete obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts and intrahepatic ducts at the hilum.
  • Typically appear by 2 to 6 weeks of age
    • Jaundice (yellowish coloration of skin and sclera)
    • Abnormally pale stools
    • Dark urine
  • Commonly associated with polysplenia or asplenia

Investigations:

  1. Liver Function Tests:
    • Increased conjugated bilirubin.
    • Markers of cholestasis:
      • 5' nucleotidase
      • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
      • GGT (Gamma-glutamyl transferase):
        • Normal: Up to 40 U/L
        • 4x elevation: Intrahepatic causes
        • 10x elevation: Extrahepatic causes
        • Exception: Low in PFIC type I and II
  2. Ultrasound:
    • High-frequency USG (HUS) for neonatal cholestasis.
    • Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected.
    • Characteristic findings:
      • Triangular cord sign (hyperechoic areas indicating fibrous/atretic bile duct)
      • Non-visualized gallbladder/micro gallbladder/gallbladder ghost
  3. Radionucleotide Study:
    • HIDA Scan (Hepatobiliary scan with Tc labelled imino-di-acetic acid):
      • Used as a screening test.
      • Decreased tracer excretion due to obstruction
    • Phenobarbitone loading/priming (5 days) to improve tracer uptake
    • Used as a screening test, not specific
  4. Best Investigation:
    • Liver biopsy: IOC for confirming diagnosis.

Surgical Management:

  •  
  • Temporary procedure: Kasai procedure/hepaticojejunostomy
  • Definitive management: Liver transplantation
  • Kasai Procedure:
    • Temporary procedure
    • Creates communication between the liver and jejunum for bile drainage
    • Should be performed within 8 weeks after birth

questions.text: Which classification system is used for bile duct injury, taking location, injury to the duct, and vessel involvement into account?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hannover

Explanation:

The Hannover classification is a comprehensive system for bile duct injuries, particularly post-cholecystectomy, that accounts for:

  • Location of injury

  • Type of duct injury (partial or complete)

  • Presence of vascular injury (e.g., to the right hepatic artery)

It provides a more detailed description compared to older systems and is especially useful in surgical planning.

  • Type A: Cystic duct or gallbladder bed leak.
  • Type B: Incomplete or complete stenosis.
  • Type C: Lateral tangential injuries.
  • Type D: Complete bile duct injury with vascular injuries.
  • Type E: Late bile duct stenosis.

Bismuth Classification: (Option A)

Describes strictures of the biliary system, particularly benign biliary strictures after surgery. It is based solely on the location of the stricture relative to the hepatic duct confluence.

Type I
  • Common hepatic duct stump >2cm
  • Stricture is Low

Type II
  • Common hepatic duct stump <2cm
  • Stricture is mid

Type III
  • Hilar stricture with intact confluence
  • Stricture is high

Type IV
  • Hilar stricture with destroyed confluence

Type V
  • Stricture involving aberrant right sectoral duct with or without stricture of common hepatic duct

 

Strasberg classification (Option B) divides bile duct injuries into five main classes:

Type A (M/C)

Cystic duct stump leak or leak from sub-vesical duct of Luschka

Type B

Ligation or occlusion of aberrant right sectoral duct

Type C

Transection without occlusion of the aberrant right sectoral duct

Type D

Injury to the lateral wall of the Common hepatic duct

Type E

E1 to E5 Bismuth classification

Stewart-Way Classification (Option C):

Focuses on mechanisms of injury and surgeon-related errors, useful for root cause analysis rather than guiding surgical repair.

Stewart-Way Classification:

  • Class I: Incomplete injury.
  • Class II: Lateral injury with bile leak and stenosis.
  • Class III: Complete transection of the common bile duct (most common, 60%).
  • Class IV: Duct branch injuries with involvement of the right hepatic artery.

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presented with RTA and is brought to ER with a pulse rate of 120/min, and SBP of <80mmHg. Despite intravenous fluid resuscitation and BT, the patient's condition deteriorates with ongoing profuse bleeding from the liver. Identify the procedure shown in the image done to control massive liver bleed.
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Pringle's maneuver

  • Pringle's maneuver involves temporarily clamping the hepatoduodenal ligament, which contains the portal vein, hepatic artery, and common bile duct.
  • This maneuver is used to control bleeding from the liver by temporarily interrupting blood flow to the liver.
  • It is a common technique used during liver surgery or to manage traumatic liver bleeding.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Kocher maneuver:

  • Kocher maneuver is a surgical technique used during cholecystectomy to mobilize the duodenum and improve access to the gallbladder.
  • It is not relevant to controlling liver bleeding.

  • Cattell-Braasch maneuver is a mobilization surgical technique that allows good access to the retroperitoneal structures.
  • The inferior vena cava, abdominal aorta below the superior mesenteric artery, and retroperitoneal organs of the right side are exposed when it is completed.

Option D - Mattox maneuver:

  • Mattox maneuver, also known as a left medial visceral rotation, is a surgical step to explore and handle Zone 1 and 2 retroperitoneal injuries (aorta, left iliac and pelvic vessels).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with abdominal pain in the emergency room. . On examination, there is blackish discoloration involving the periumbilical skin. What is the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A - Acute Pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis is characterized by inflammation of the pancreas and can cause severe abdominal pain. However, it typically doesn't lead to blackish discoloration of the perineal skin. Hypotension may occur in severe cases due to systemic inflammation and fluid shifts, but the perineal discoloration is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis.

  • Presents with cullens sign

Incorrect Options:

 Option B - Necrotizing Fasciitis:

  • Deeper tissue injury, usually from anaerobic bacteria or S pyogenes. Pain may be out of proportion to exam findings.
  • Results in crepitus from methane and CO2 production.
  • “Flesh-eating bacteria.” Causes bullae and skin necrosis causing violaceous color of bullae, surrounding skin .
  • Surgical emergency

Option C - Chronic Pancreatitis: Chronic pancreatitis is a long-standing inflammation of the pancreas, often due to alcohol abuse or other underlying factors. It leads to persistent abdominal pain, digestive issues, and potentially complications over time. However, it is unlikely to cause the rapid onset of perineal skin discoloration and hypotension as seen in the given presentation.

Option D - Traumatic Fat Necrosis: Traumatic fat necrosis can occur as a result of physical trauma to fatty tissues, leading to localized inflammation and tissue damage. While it can cause skin discoloration, it typically presents as a localized issue rather than involving the perineal skin. It's also less likely to cause the severe systemic symptoms, including hypotension, seen in this case.

  • It has no pathological significance and does not affect gallbladder function.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. • Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

 

Indications

Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localised to the head of the pancreas. 

Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management. 

Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct (distal cholangiocarcinoma), and ampulla of Vater. (Option C)

Procedure Steps

Tumor Assessment: Explore the abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread. 

Resection: Remove the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of the bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection. 

Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction

Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect the remaining pancreas to the jejunum. Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to the jejunum. Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles

Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing. 

Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy

Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications

• Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues. 

• Delayed Gastric Emptying

• Bleeding, wound infection

• Reoperation, increased mortality 

• Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple, the pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

Advanced gastric carcinoma (Option A): Treatment depends on tumour location. For proximal tumours, extended gastrectomy with D2 lymphadenectomy is done; for middle tumours, total gastrectomy; and for distal tumours, subtotal gastrectomy. The Whipple procedure is specific to pancreaticoduodenal cancers, not gastric carcinoma.

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option B): Treatment involves an extended cholecystectomy, which includes removal of the liver segments, gallbladder, and surrounding lymph nodes. The Whipple procedure is not typically used unless the tumour invades the bile duct or pancreas.

Chronic calcific pancreatitis (Option D): Treatment involves enzyme supplementation, pain management with NSAIDs and opioids, and procedures like ERCP with stenting or drainage. The Whipple procedure is not the first choice; instead, pancreaticojejunostomy or drainage surgeries are preferred based on the extent of the  damage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic patient presents with a history of waxing and waning jaundice for the past 2 months. His CT examination reveals dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. What is the most probable diagnosis in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

Explanation:

The scenario of an alcoholic patient experiencing fluctuating jaundice, with a CT scan showing dilation of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, is most likely indicative of Periampullary Carcinoma.

  • It originates in the pancreas, bile duct, or intestines close to the ampulla of Vater (the region where the common bile duct and pancreatic duct converge and enter the duodenum).
  • They can cause obstruction of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct.
  • Clinical features:
    • Jaundice (waxing and waning) (most common)
    • A palpable, non-tender gallbladder
    • Weight loss
    • Abdominal pain
    • Nausea/vomiting
    • Pruritus
    • Fever
    • Gastrointestinal bleeding

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option A) arises from the bile ducts and can cause common bile duct dilatation. However, the waxing and waning jaundice and dilatation of the pancreatic duct, in this case, are more indicative of periampullary carcinoma. Cholangiocarcinoma usually presents with more progressive jaundice.

Common bile duct stone (Option C) can cause ductal dilatation, but the waxing and waning jaundice and pancreatic duct involvement make periampullary carcinoma more likely. Bile duct stones typically cause acute, not fluctuating, jaundice.

Head of the pancreas carcinoma (Option D) can cause ductal dilatation, but periampullary carcinoma is a more specific diagnosis given the involvement of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. Pancreatic cancer typically presents with continuous jaundice, not fluctuating.

questions.text: A chronic-alcoholic presents to the emergency room with acute pain in the abdomen in the epigastric region radiating to the back with nausea, anorexia, and occasional vomiting. Investigations showed elevated amylase levels (3 times) and total count. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

The scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, along with nausea, anorexia, occasional vomiting, and elevated amylase levels and total count, is indicative of Acute Pancreatitis.

Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3):

  • Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. (Option B)
  • Serum amylase and/or lipase (more specific) level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal. (Option B)
  • Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis.

X-ray Features
  • Sentinel loop sign:
    • Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.
    • Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign
  • Colon cut-off sign:
    • Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.
    • Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

Investigations of Choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications.
    • Most reliable for staging and detecting complications.
    • May underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours.

Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  • Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis: Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis.
  • Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality.

 

Acute hepatitis (Option A) is liver inflammation, often caused by viral infections, alcohol, or toxins, with symptoms like jaundice, fatigue, dark urine, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST). This diagnosis is unlikely for the patient, as her symptoms of epigastric pain, elevated amylase, and the absence of jaundice or liver enzyme elevation point more toward pancreatitis.

Acute Cholecystitis (Option C), caused by gallstones, presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea, with ultrasound showing gallstones or thickened walls. However, the patient's epigastric pain and elevated amylase suggest pancreatitis, not cholecystitis.

Acute appendicitis (Option D) presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, elevated white blood cell count, and pain that starts around the umbilicus, shifting to the lower right abdomen. In this case, the patient has epigastric pain and elevated amylase, making appendicitis unlikely, as it doesn’t typically affect amylase levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best preferred investigation for Neuroendocrine Tumors (NETs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) PET

Explanation:

The investigation of choice for the localization of Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (PNETs) is SRS (somatostatin receptor scintigraphy).

  • They are derived from pleuripotent stem cells.
  • Classified as functional and non-functional PNETs
  • Subtypes:
    • Insulinoma (most common functional PNET)
    • Gastrinoma (most common functional and malignant PNET)
    • Non-functional tumors
    • VIPoma
    • Glucagonoma
    • Somatostatinoma
    • Carcinoid
    • ACTHoma
    • GRFoma
  • It is symptomatic and diagnosed at an early stage.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Laboratory measurement of active substances or its by products.
    • PET (Positron Emission Tomography)/CT: Preferred investigation for NETs nowadays. (Option D)
      • Tracer: 68Gallium (68Ga)-labeled somatostatin analogs
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) is used for the localization of NETs. (IOC).
      • All Neuroendocrine tumors express Somatostatin receptors except Insulinoma.
      • It is not used nowadays. (Option B ruled out)

 

USG (ultrasound) (Option A) is not the best choice for pancreatic NETs because the pancreas is deep in the abdomen, making it hard to visualize. It is useful for detecting large masses but is less sensitive for smaller tumors or those without distinct features.

MRI (Option C) is useful for pancreatic tumors and liver metastases but lacks the functional detail of SRS. SRS is the gold standard for detecting somatostatin receptor-positive NETs.
